title: 114_s2932
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protecting Patient Access to Emergency Medications Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the importance of controlled substances for emergency medical services to save lives and improve health outcomes. There is a need for regulatory oversight to prevent diversion in all healthcare settings, including emergency medical services. Regulatory oversight is crucial to prevent diversion of controlled substances in emergency medical services. Oversight should be tailored to different care delivery models and promote uniform rules to prevent diversion and establish clear guidelines within emergency medical services. SEC. 312 of the Controlled Substances Act adds regulations for emergency medical services to prevent diversion of controlled substances. The Controlled Substances Act defines emergency medical services as medical response provided outside of a facility, and emergency medical services agency as an organization providing such services. An emergency medical services practitioner is a licensed healthcare provider credentialed to provide emergency medical services. An emergency medical services practitioner is a licensed healthcare provider authorized by a medical director to provide emergency medical services. Medical oversight involves supervising the medical operations of an emergency medical services agency. Standing orders are written protocols for administering controlled substances, while verbal orders are verbal prescriptions for the same purpose. The curr_chunk discusses definitions related to administering controlled substances in emergency medical services, including terms like verbal order, online medical direction, and registrant emergency medical services agency. It also mentions the registration process for enabling practitioners to dispense controlled substances. The Attorney General can register emergency medical services agencies under their own hospital license to enable practitioners to dispense controlled substances. A single registration per State is required, tailored guidance will be provided to registrants. The Attorney General requires a single registration per State for emergency medical services agencies, with tailored guidance provided to recognize existing medical care delivery models. Each agency must have one or more licensed medical directors for oversight. The emergency medical services agency must have one or more licensed medical directors responsible for overseeing patient care and making decisions on transportation destinations and medical protocols. The licensed medical directors oversee patient care, medical protocols, online medical direction, drug formularies, medical education, training programs, and quality improvement for the emergency medical services agency. The licensed medical directors oversee patient care, medical protocols, online medical direction, drug formularies, medical education, training programs, and quality improvement for the emergency medical services agency. They also have the authority to delegate the administration of controlled substances in schedule II-V to emergency medical services practitioners under standing orders or online medical direction. The licensed medical directors can issue standing orders or online medical direction for emergency medical services practitioners in specific circumstances, such as for a specific patient or during mass casualty incidents. The medical director can provide verbal orders for emergency medical services practitioners during mass casualty incidents or specific patient situations without needing to be present or provide a written prescription. A registrant emergency medical services agency is not required to be present or provide a prescription for administering controlled substances. They must keep standing orders on file and have a policy for documenting verbal orders and controlled substance administrations in patient care charts. The registrant emergency medical services agency can receive, move, and store controlled substances as needed. Controlled substance administrations must be documented in patient care charts and made available to the Attorney General upon request. The registrant emergency medical services agency can store controlled substances at designated locations and must document administrations in patient care charts. This section does not affect requirements under the Social Security Act or limit the Attorney General's authority to enforce controlled substance diversion.
